itemDescription: English recipient of the Victoria Cross

wikipedia_page.main: General Sir John Watson,  (6 September 1829 – 23 January 1919) was an English recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces. An officer serving with the Bengal Army, Watson received his Victoria Cross for actions at Lucknow during the Indian Mutiny. He later rose to the rank of general in the British Indian Army.

#REDIRECT John Watson (Indian Army officer)

The museum is set up in the Queen Victoria memorial institute buildings located in Jubilee Garden, Rajkot. The museum was named in fond memory of Colonel John Watson in 1888 who was a British political agent of Kathiawar Agency from 1881 to 1889. Watson Museum is the second most important museum in Gujarat, after the Museum of Baroda and is the oldest museum in Saurashtra (region). Colonel Watson was fond of history and archaeology and used to collect information on Rajkot. Most of his collections and other artifacts are preserved here. The museum building was completed in 1893, and opened to the public by Governor Lord George Harris of Bombay Presidency."Visit Rajkot", Retrieved on 5 December 2008
*General Sir John Watson : Commanded the regiment in 1871 and was recipient of Victoria Cross.
Sir John Watson may refer to:
* Sir John Watson Gordon (1788–1864), Scottish painter
* Sir John Watson (polo), English polo player and winner of the International Polo Cup in 1876

* Sir John Watson (advocate) (1883–1944), Scottish advocate and sheriff, Solicitor General for Scotland 1929–31
#REDIRECT John Watson (Indian Army officer)
Major-General Sir Harry Davis Watson, KBE, CB, CMG, CIE, MVO (18 July 1866 – 7 May 1945) was a British Army officer. He was the son of General Sir John Watson.The Times, Obituary, 8 May 1945

He married Minnie Richbell. They had three daughters, Violet Sylvia (b. 1894 in E. India), Ethel Douglas (b. 1896 in Bengal), and Dorothy Mabel (b. 1899 in Bengal). In 1920 Ethel Douglas Lace married a grandson of General Sir John Watson.
